facts.text: Suraj Bhan was abducted from his house in Rajgarh on November 12, 1954, by two masked men, one armed with a revolver.

anchor.surface_text: On November 12,1954, when Suraj Bhan was at his desk in his house, somebody made an enquiry whether one Rameshwar was there, to which Suraj Bhan replied in the negative. A few minutes thereafter, two men with masks entered the room and one of them was armed with a revolver. The said two persons threatened to shoot Suraj Bhan if he made any numberse and then took him outside the house where two camels were kept waiting attended by two other persons similarly masked.

facts.text: Suraj Bhan was taken to the house of Deep Chand in village Kalari and confined there in a small room for 17 days.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, Suraj Bhan was taken to the house of Dee Chand, the appellant, in village Kalari and was kept there in companyfinement in a small room for 17 days. During the entire period he was kept blindfolded.

facts.text: Suraj Bhan was kept blindfolded during the entire 17 days of confinement in Deep Chand's house.

anchor.surface_text: During the entire period he was kept blindfolded. Two or three days after the abduction, Suraj Bhan was made to write three letters to his father and put down his fathers address on the envelopes.

facts.text: Suraj Bhan was made to write three letters to his father Kashiram under duress two or three days after abduction.

anchor.surface_text: Two or three days after the abduction, Suraj Bhan was made to write three letters to his father and put down his fathers address on the envelopes. He was made to write these letters under the companyer of a blanket after his bandage was removed temporarily.

facts.text: Suraj Bhan was removed to the house of Lachhman on November 29, 1954, and confined there till release.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile, to facilitate the smooth companyduct of the negotiations, on November 29, 1954, Suraj Bhan was removed to the house of one Lachhman and was companyfined there till his release.

facts.text: Ransom of Rs. 50,000 was paid to Dhannaram and Deep Chand on December 17, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The sum of Rs. 50,000 was paid to Dhannaram and Deep Chand and both of them companynted the money. The money was paid on December 17,1954, and Suraj Bhan was released on December 20, 1954.

facts.text: Suraj Bhan was released on December 20, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The money was paid on December 17,1954, and Suraj Bhan was released on December 20, 1954.

facts.text: Deep Chand identified by Suraj Bhan as one of the abductors on November 12, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Suraj Bhan stated in his evidence that when he was writing his accounts at about 7-15 p.m. in his house on November 12, 1954, two persons with their faces companyered with masks entered his house and by threatening to shoot him, forcibly took him away on one of the two camels brought by them. He further alleged that he recognized one of the abductors who threatened him with a revolver as Deep Chand, as he was a local Congressman known to Suraj Bhan from before.

facts.text: Suraj Bhan confined in Deep Chand's house for 17 days, identified the house and heard Deep Chand's voice.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the second stage, namely, the companyfinement of Suraj Bhan in Deep Chands house, the High Court accepted the evidence of Suraj Bhan identifying the said house by giving particulars thereof. Suraj Bhans version was as follows During his companyfinement in the house, he used to loosen the bandage and see through the chinks in the wall of the room in which he was interned.

facts.text: Suraj Bhan shifted to Lachhman's house by Deep Chand.

anchor.surface_text: This evidence proves that Suraj Bhan was shifted by Deep Chand to the house of Lachhman on the eve of the negotiations.

facts.text: Rs. 50,000 ransom paid to Deep Chand by Shiv Bhagwan and Durga Parshad.

anchor.surface_text: Then there is the evidence of Shiv Bhagwan and Durga Parshad, who actually paid the ransom. These witnesses spoke about the negotiations and also the actual payment of Rs. 50,000 to Deep Chand.

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge, Churu convicted Deep Chand under sections 347, 365, 386 IPC on May 3, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: confirming the Judgment of the Additional Sessions Judge, Churu, dated May 3, 1957, in so far as he companyvicted the appellant under ss. 347, 365 and 386, Indian Penal Code, and setting aside his order acquitting the appellant under s. 458, Indian Penal Code, and companyvicting the appellant under s. 452, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Sessions Judge sentenced Deep Chand to 1 year RI under s.347, 2 years under s.365, 3.5 years under s.386 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Additional Sessions Judge sentenced the appellant for the offences under ss. 347, 365 and 386, Indian Penal Code, to undergo rigorous imprisonment for I year, 2 years and 3 1/2 years respectively.

facts.text: Sessions Judge acquitted Deep Chand under s.458 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: setting aside his order acquitting the appellant under s. 458, Indian Penal Code

facts.text: Rajasthan High Court on August 1, 1958 enhanced sentences and convicted under s.452 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 1, 1958, of the Rajasthan High Court, at Jodhpur in Criminal Appeal Nos. 98 and 155 of 1957 and Criminal Revision No. 116 of 1957.

facts.text: High Court enhanced sentence under s.347 to 3 years RI, s.386 to 8 years RI and fine Rs.20,000, confirmed s.365 at 2 years.

anchor.surface_text: Tile High Court enhanced the sentences in respect of the offences under so. 347 and 386, Indian Penal Code, to 3 years and 8 years respectively, and also imposed a fine of Rs. 20,000 on the appellant the sentence in regard to the offence under s. 365, Indian Penal Code, was companyfirmed.

facts.text: High Court convicted Deep Chand under s.352 IPC to 7 years RI.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court further found that the appellant was guilty under s. 352, Indian Penal Code, also and for that offence it sentenced him to undergo rigorous imprisonment for 7 years.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal by special leave, Criminal Appeal No. 156 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 156 of 1960. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 1, 1958, of the Rajasthan High Court, at Jodhpur in Criminal Appeal Nos. 98 and 155 of 1957 and Criminal Revision No. 116 of 1957.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on March 30, 1961 by Subba Rao J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. March 30. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SUBBA RAO, J.-This is an appeal by special leave against the judgment of the High Court of Judicature for Rajasthan dated August 1, 1958,

facts.text: Kashiram was a prosperous businessman residing at Sidhmugh.

anchor.surface_text: At the outset it would be companyvenient to state briefly the case of the prosecution. One Kashiram, a prosperous businessman, was residing at Sidhmugh. His only son Suraj Bhan was living at Rajgarh where lie was carrying on an independent business of his own.

facts.text: Suraj Bhan was carrying on independent business at Rajgarh.

anchor.surface_text: His only son Suraj Bhan was living at Rajgarh where lie was carrying on an independent business of his own. On November 12,1954, when Suraj Bhan was at his desk in his house,

facts.text: Sessions Judge acquitted Ramji Lal, Dhannaram, Jiwan Ram; convicted Sisram under 347,365 but acquitted by HC.

anchor.surface_text: Five persons, namely, Deep Chand, Sisram, Jiwan Ram, Dhannaram and Ramji Lal, were prosecuted in the Sessions Court for the aforesaid offences. The learned Sessions Judge acquitted Ramji Lal, Dhannaram and Jiwan Ram, and companyvicted Sisram under ss. 347 and 365, Indian Penal Code, and Deep Chand as aforesaid.

facts.text: Magistrate Devisingh conducted verification at Deep Chand's house, prepared plan Ex. P-28 and memo Ex. P-27.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate took Suraj Bhan along with him to the house of Deep Chand. He inspected the house and got the plan, Ex. P-28, prepared under his supervision by P.W. 25, the Reserve Inspector, Churu. He also recorded the memorandum, Ex. P-27,

facts.text: Chinks in the wall of Deep Chand's confinement room were recently closed and new rooms constructed in 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The memorandum prepared by the Magistrate, his evidence and the evidence of P.Ws. 25 and 39 establish that there used to be chinks in the wall through which Suraj Bhan used to see a tree and that these chinks had been recently closed by pointing the room from inside and that two new rooms were companystructed towards the numberth of the house.

facts.text: Lachhman kept Suraj Bhan for 21 days on request from Deep Chand and Jiwan Ram.

anchor.surface_text: Lachhman, as W. 3, deposed that on a request made by Jiwan Ram on behalf of Deep Chand he agreed to keep a lady whom Jiwan Ram and Deep Chand would bring to his house for a few days and on the next day, Deep Chand and Sisram brought in the midnight Suraj Bhan instead of a lady.

issues.text: Whether the High Court erred in relying upon the statement made by Suraj Bhan before the Magistrate at the time of verification proceedings, though it was not recorded in compliance with the provisions of s. 164 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, and if excluded, whether the High Court would have accepted the evidence of confinement in Deep Chand's house

anchor.surface_text: 1  The High Court erred in relying upon the statement made by Suraj Bhan before the Magistrate at the time of verification proceedings, though it was number recorded in compliance with the provisions of s. 164 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, and if the said statement and the verification proceedings based on that statement were excluded, it is number possible to predicate that the High Court would have accepted the evidence -of Suraj Bhan in respect of his version that he was companyfined in the house of Deep Chand.

issues.text: Whether the High Court went wrong in upholding the privilege claimed by Shri S. Gajender Singh, the District Magistrate, in respect of important questions put to him in cross-examination

anchor.surface_text: 2  The High Court also went wrong in upholding the privilege claimed by Shri S. Gajender Singh, the District Magistrate, in respect of important questions put to him in the cross examination and if the claim of privilege had number been upheld, answers would have been elicited from him which might have established that Suraj Bhan was lying in the witness-stand and that his previous statements represented the truth.

issues.text: Whether the High Court erred in setting aside the order acquitting the appellant under s. 458, Indian Penal Code, without sufficient and compelling reasons and in convicting him under s. 452, Indian Penal Code

anchor.surface_text: 3  The High Court erred also in setting aside the order acquitting the appellant under s. 458, Indian Penal Code, without sufficient and companypelling reasons and in companyvicting him under s. 452, Indian Penal Code.

issues.text: Whether a Magistrate's evidence of facts establishing identity from verification proceedings is admissible under s. 9 of the Evidence Act notwithstanding non-compliance with s. 164 CrPC for recording statements

anchor.surface_text: The relevant provisions are s. 164 of the Code of Criminal Procedure and s. 9 of the Evidence Act. ... If a statement of a witness recorded by a Magistrate in derogation of the provisions of s. 164 will go in as evidence under s. 9 of the Evidence Act, the object of s. 164 of the said Code will be defeated. It is, therefore, necessary to resort to the rule of harmonious companystruction so as to give full effect to both the provisions.

issues.text: Whether there are exceptional circumstances warranting departure from the usual practice of accepting concurrent findings of fact by the courts below

anchor.surface_text: It is the usual practice of this Court to accept the companycurrent findings of fact arrived at by the companyrts below and there are numberexceptional circumstances in this case to depart from the usual practice.

issues.text: Whether the question of privilege claimed by Gajender Singh is entertainable before the Supreme Court when not raised before the High Court

anchor.surface_text: That apart, the question of privilege was number raised before the High Court. In the circumstances, we would number be justified in allowing the appellant to raise before us the question of privilege based upon the disallowance of a few questions put to one of the witnesses.

issues.text: Whether the High Court was justified in enhancing the sentences imposed by the Sessions Judge

anchor.surface_text: Finally learned counsel for the appellant made an impassioned appeal on the question of sentence. ... When the Sessions Judge gave such a disproportionately lenient sentences, it was the duty of the High Court to rectify such an obvious error. In our view, the learned Judges of the High Court rightly enhanced the sentence imposed on the appellant.

arguments.claim: Overwhelming evidence shows Deep Chand detained Suraj Bhan in his house then Lachhman's and released on ransom; but insufficient evidence of participation in initial abduction

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge, on a consideration of the entire evidence placed before him, held that there was overwhelming evidence to show that Deep Chand detained Suraj Bhan in his house for sometime and thereafter in Lachhmans house and released him on payment of a ransom. But he held that there was no sufficient evidence to find definitely that Deep Chand participated in the abduction of Suraj Bhan on November 12, 1954, from the latters house.

arguments.qualifiers: no sufficient evidence to find definitely

arguments.claim: Deep Chand participated in abduction on November 12, 1954; convicted under s.452 IPC instead of s.458 acquittal

anchor.surface_text: Disagreeing with the Sessions Judge, the High Court further held that it had been established on the evidence that Deep Chand was one of the persons who abducted Suraj Bhan from his house on November 12, 1954. In the result, the High Court convicted the appellant not only under ss. 347, 365 and 386, Indian Penal Code, but also under s. 452 thereof.

arguments.claim: Usual practice to accept concurrent findings of fact by courts below; no exceptional circumstances here to depart

anchor.surface_text: It is the usual practice of this Court to accept the concurrent findings of fact arrived at by the courts below and there are no exceptional circumstances in this case to depart from the usual practice.

arguments.claim: Magistrate's evidence of facts establishing identity from verification relevant under s.9 Evidence Act even if statements not recorded per s.164 CrPC

anchor.surface_text: The relevant provisions are s. 164 of the Code of Criminal Procedure and s. 9 of the Evidence Act. ... If a statement of a witness recorded by a Magistrate in derogation of the provisions of s. 164 will go in as evidence under s. 9 of the Evidence Act, the object of s. 164 of the said Code will be defeated. It is, therefore, necessary to resort to the rule of harmonious construction so as to give full effect to both the provisions.

arguments.claim: Unrecorded statements to Magistrate during investigation inadmissible per Nazir Ahmad principle and s.164 CrPC requirements

anchor.surface_text: where power is given to do a certain thing in a certain way, the thing must be done in that way or not at all

arguments.claim: Verification proceedings evidence admissible for identity facts but not unrecorded statements, per precedents like Amiruddin Ahmed

anchor.surface_text: This decision is an authority for the position that the evidence given by a Magistrate on the basis of the verification proceedings conducted by him is relevant evidence though he could not speak of statements made by the accused or a witness recorded by him in contravention of s. 164 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

arguments.claim: Privilege question not entertainable as not raised before High Court

anchor.surface_text: That apart, the question of privilege was not raised before the High Court. In the circumstances, we would not be justified in allowing the appellant to raise before us the question of privilege based upon the disallowance of a few questions put to one of the witnesses.

arguments.claim: Suraj Bhan's identification of Deep Chand as abductor credible given prior acquaintance, voice, stature, and continuous custody

anchor.surface_text: Suraj Bhan stated in his evidence that when he was writing his accounts at about 7-15 p.m. in his house on November 12, 1954, two persons with their faces covered with masks entered his house and by threatening to shoot him, forcibly took him away on one of the two camels brought by them. He further alleged that he recognized one of the abductors who threatened him with a revolver as Deep Chand, as he was a local Congressman known to Suraj Bhan from before.

arguments.claim: High Court justified in enhancing sentences as Sessions Judge's were disproportionately lenient for grave heinous crime warranting exemplary punishment

anchor.surface_text: When the Sessions Judge gave such a disproportionately lenient sentences, it was the duty of the High Court to rectify such an obvious error. In our view, the learned Judges of the High Court rightly enhanced the sentence imposed on the appellant.

holdings.text: The evidence of the Magistrate from verification proceedings, excluding unrecorded statements of Suraj Bhan, is admissible under s.9 of the Evidence Act as facts establishing identity, but unrecorded statements are inadmissible due to non-compliance with s.164 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant provisions are s. 164 of the Code of Criminal Procedure and s. 9 of the Evidence Act. ... We, therefore, hold that the evidence of the Magistrate, excluding that part pertaining to the statements made to him by Suraj Bhan, was relevant evidence in the case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction reconciles s.164 CrPC (mandatory recording) with s.9 Evidence Act (identity facts relevant); Nazir Ahmad principle applies; precedents like Amiruddin distinguish factual observations from statements; exclusion does not affect outcome due to other corroboration.

holdings.text: Magistrate's unrecorded statements during investigation are inadmissible per s.164 CrPC and Nazir Ahmad principle where power given in certain way must be done that way or not at all.

anchor.surface_text: where power is given to do a certain thing in a certain way, the thing must be done in that way or number at all, and other methods of performance are necessarily forbidden.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Judicial Committee in Nazir Ahmad; statutory safeguards in ss.164/364 CrPC cannot be bypassed; policy to prevent unregulated witness testimony.

holdings.text: Question of privilege claimed by Gajender Singh not entertainable in Supreme Court as not raised before High Court.

anchor.surface_text: That apart, the question of privilege was number raised before the High Court. In the circumstances, we would number be justified in allowing the appellant to raise before us the question of privilege based upon the disallowance of a few questions put to one of the witnesses.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural bar: new points not raised in lower court not permitted in SC; courts independently accepted Suraj Bhan's credibility without relying on disallowed evidence.

holdings.text: No exceptional circumstances to depart from usual practice of accepting concurrent findings of fact by courts below.

anchor.surface_text: It is the usual practice of this Court to accept the companycurrent findings of fact arrived at by the companyrts below and there are numberexceptional circumstances in this case to depart from the usual practice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deference to concurrent factual findings absent perversity or exceptional circumstances; overwhelming evidence supports guilt on all charges.

holdings.text: High Court justified in setting aside acquittal under s.458 IPC and convicting under s.452 IPC based on Suraj Bhan's credible identification of Deep Chand as abductor.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court companysidered, and in our view rightly that there was numberreason to disbelieve the evidence of Suraj Bhan when he identified Deep Chand at the time of abduction. Suraj Bhan knew the accused before and he also knew his stature and voice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Suraj Bhan's prior acquaintance, recognition by voice/stature despite mask, continuous custody from abduction to release; no reason to disbelieve.

holdings.text: High Court rightly enhanced sentences as Sessions Judge's were disproportionately lenient for grave heinous crime warranting exemplary punishment.

anchor.surface_text: When the Sessions Judge gave such a disproportionately lenient sentences, it was the duty of the High Court to rectify such an obvious error. In our view, the learned Judges of the High Court rightly enhanced the sentence imposed on the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sessions sentences (1yr s.347, 2yr s.365, 3.5yr s.386 concurrent) inadequate for kidnapping/extortion; High Court duty to correct leniency in heinous cases.

anchor.surface_text: Nazir Ahmad v. The King-Emperor  1  is rather instructive. There, a Magistrate gave evidence in court on the strength of a confession made to him which was not recorded under s. 164 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. The question was whether the said evidence was admissible against the accused.

precedents.cited_proposition: where power is given to do a certain thing in a certain way, the thing must be done in that way or not at all; Magistrates cannot give evidence of statements or confessions not recorded under s. 164 CrPC
precedents.cited_holding: Evidence by Magistrate of unrecorded confession inadmissible

precedents.citation: Legal Remembrancer Lalit Mohan Singh Roy  1

anchor.surface_text: Legal Remembrancer Lalit Mohan Singh Roy  1 , a Magistrate sought to give evidence of an unrecorded statement made to him by the accused. The court rightly held that it was not permissible. The same remarks we made in regard to the decision of the Privy Council would apply to this case.

precedents.case_name: Legal Remembrancer v. Lalit Mohan Singh Roy
precedents.cited_proposition: Magistrate cannot give evidence of unrecorded statement made by accused

anchor.surface_text: Amiruddin Ahmed v. Emperor  2 , a Magistrate conducted verification proceedings with a view to test the truth of a confession made by the accused. Teunon, J., made the following observations at p. 564 They are undertaken, it would seem, with a view

precedents.cited_proposition: Verification proceedings by Magistrate relevant for facts observed, but statements made during not recorded under s.164 CrPC are inadmissible
precedents.cited_holding: Statements in verification not recorded per s.164 inadmissible; facts for identification useful

anchor.surface_text: Jitendra Nath v. Emperor  1 . In that case, the learned Judges observed at p. 110 thus In one case there was a verification report so far as the confessional statement of an accused person was concerned, which it would appear was fairly A.I.R. 1937 Cal. 99.

precedents.cited_proposition: Verification report by Magistrate admissible if Magistrate testifies to contents; but statements by accused to verifying Magistrate not recorded under s.164 CrPC inadmissible
precedents.cited_holding: Magistrate's testimony to verification report admissible; unrecorded statements inadmissible

anchor.surface_text: Finally learned counsel for the appellant made an impassioned appeal on the question of sentence. He said that the learned Sessions Judge had awarded a reasonable sentence to the accused and the High Court was number justified in enhancing the said sentence. The Sessions Judge held that the accused was guilty of a grave and heinous crime and we are surprised that he should have sentenced the accused to undergo rigorous imprisonment for one year under s. 347, 2 years under s. 365 and 3 1/2 years under s. 386, Indian Penal Code, and direct the sentences to run concurrently. When the Sessions Judge gave such a disproportionately lenient sentences, it was the duty of the High Court to rectify such an obvious error. In our view, the learned Judges of the High Court rightly enhanced the sentence imposed on the appellant.

outcome.relief_summary: All contentions of the appellant rejected; High Court conviction under ss. 347, 365, 386, 452 IPC and enhanced sentences upheld

anchor.surface_text: Finally learned counsel for the appellant made an impassioned appeal on the question of sentence. He said that the learned Sessions Judge had awarded a reasonable sentence to the accused and the High Court was number justified in enhancing the said sentence. The Sessions Judge held that the accused was guilty of a grave and heinous crime and we are surprised that he should have sentenced the accused to undergo rigorous imprisonment for one year under s. 347, 2 years under s. 365 and 3 1/2 years under s. 386, Indian Penal Code, and direct the sentences to run concurrently. When the Sessions Judge gave such a disproportionately lenient sentences, it was the duty of the High Court to rectify such an obvious error. In our view, the learned Judges of the High Court rightly enhanced the sentence imposed on the appellant.
